name: Charles Kimbrough

name: Anne Hutchinson

name: Ja'Net DuBois
subtitle: Actress, Good Times
blurb: Ja’Net DuBois—Willona from TV’s Good Times—won our hearts not just for her neighborly no-nonsense behavior and for the head-scratching apostrophe in her name, but for belting out as well as writing the Jeffersons theme—one of the best in history. She edges out barfly Charles Bukowski and MANFRED S. LUBOWITZ—better known as Manfred Mann—who at 16 letters is the longest supervocalic person with no repeated letters.

name: Jehan Cousin

JEHAN COUSIN purportedly sailed to Brazil in 1488, 4 years before Columbus set sail. One of his captains left in anger, subsequently sailing with Columbus.

Also contending is JEAN LOUIS with 14 Oscar noms and a win for costume design, who designed Marilyn Monroe's "Happy Birthday, Mr. President" dress. They don't get much more "notable" than that.

name: Xochiquetzal
subtitle: Aztec goddess of fertility
blurb: In the pantheon of supervocalic discoveries, XOCHIQUETZAL reigns supereme. She is also the embodiment of the Divine Feminine and all it represents. Like a true goddess, she nurtures - welcoming not only all vowels, but 3 of the 4 highest-scoring Scrabble tiles others find "difficult". And like a working Mom handling kids and groceries, she does this in one solid word, without so much as a space, leading with the rare and sultry "X" as if to say "I got this". The supervocalic Mother Goddess, watching over the mortal Moctezuma I.
AskDmitri: OIUEA Rossif Sutherland 80 Shoji Ueda 75 Corin Curschellas 73 Moritz Gudemann 68 Florin Prunea 62 Xochiquetzal - Aztec goddess of fertility

name: Douglas Leigh
subtitle: Sign designer, many NYC landmarks
blurb: Another entrant feted for his creations if not his name recognition, DOUGLAS LEIGH was a visionary in the field of "urban installations", responsible for some of the most enduring concepts of the 20th century. Not only did he personally oversee the transformation of Times Square into a nocturnal neon extravangza (he once owned One Times Square, where the ball drops each New Years Eve), but he came up with the idea to light up the Empire State Building red, white, and blue during the bicentennial, starting a grand tradition in the process.
AskDmitri: OUAEI Douglas Feith 80 Jourdan Lewis 80 Joshua Ferris 75 Mourad Meghni 72 Douglas Evill 70

name: Louis the Fat
subtitle: Epithet of King Louis VI of France
blurb: While LOUIS REARD invented the bikini, it was LOUIS THE FAT who really "let it hang out". He had put on so much weight that by his 40's he could no longer join the many battles he ordered waged against encroaching Normans and others. His official bio was called "The Deeds of Louis the Fat", and that was written by his best friend. But he was strong leader, and strong entry for the OUEIA slot.
AskDmitri: OUIEA Pontus Tidemand 94 Louis Menand 85 Louis Delmas 79 Louis Rhead 78 Louise Pratt 76

name: Gustav Weisskopf
subtitle: German-American aviation pioneer
blurb: GUSTAV WEISSKOPF (later: WHITEHEAD) was a fasicinating figure who either needed a better Publicist, or to have his momma scold him for telling tales. Meaning he either conquered powered manned flight years before the Wright Brothers, numerous times - tantalizingly leaving eyewitness but no photographic evidence - OR repeatedly lied about the same along with supposed onlookers. His bio is a good read either way.

name: Juan Diego

blurb: The first canonized indigenous Mexican, JUAN DIEGO - born Cuauhtlatoatzin - is our 3rd entry with a Nahuatl name. He had visions of the Virgin of Guadeloupe which became celbrated worldwide. The name "Diego" evolved from a family of names related to "Jacob" (San Diego = Santiago > Sant Iago > Iacobus/ Jacobus/Jacob/Yakov/Giacobus/Giacomo/Giacomus/Jacomus/James
